metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: BNUNET soil moisture and LST observation dataset in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin from  Sep., 2013 to Mar., 2014
metadata.description:
This data set includes 26 bnunet nodes in the 0.5 °× 0.5 ° observation matrix around Zhangye City in the middle reaches of Heihe River from September 2013 to March 2014. The configuration of 26 nodes is the same, including 3 layers of soil temperature probe with depth of 1cm, 5cm and 10cm and 1 layer of soil moisture probe with depth of 5cm. The observation frequency is 2 hours. This data set can provide spatiotemporal continuous observation data set for remote sensing authenticity test of surface heterogeneity and ecological hydrology research. The time is UTC + 8.            
Please refer to "bnunet data document. Docx" for details

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Monitoring surface radiation budget by remote sensing technique is a very important use of satellite data. Especially for surface solar radiation (SSR), the earliest studies can date back to the 60s of the last century (Fritz, Rao, & Weinstein, 1964). Besides large and continuous spatio-temporal coverage, another main advantage of the satellite remote sensing technique over other approaches (e.g., discrete surface observation or reanalysis modelled products) is that it can accurately capture the spatial distributions and dynamic changes of cloud, which is regarded as a superior modulator of SSR (Forman & Margulis, 2009). Up to now, over decades of rapid development, estimation of SSR based on satellite remote sensing technique has become increasingly mature, and many products have already been produced (Liang, Wang, Zhang, & Wild, 2010; Pinker & Laszlo, 1992; Pinker et al., 2003; Posselt, Mueller, Stockli, & Trentmann, 2012; Zhang, Liang, Zhou, Wu, & Zhao, 2014; Zhang, Rossow, Lacis, Oinas, & Mishchenko, 2004).

In general, the validation of products, whether at the kilometer-level or grid-level, is conducted via a direct comparison of collocated estimates from products with ground-based SSR measurements. However, the spatial nature of satellite remote sensing products and that of ground-based measurements are totally different. Essentially, what kilometer-level or pixel-level products provide are the areal retrieved values over the footprints of satellite pixels; what grid-level products give are the means within latitude-longitude grids; whereas ground-based measurements are point-specific. They are three distinct spatial samplings on surface radiation fields and embody the space attributes of kilometer-scale, grid-scale, and point-scale, respectively. Such scale diversity poses the following question: how well do surface point measurements represent the larger scale surrounding means characterized by satellite remote sensing products? If the error originating from their unique spatial sampling scales is defined as representativeness error, how large is it in the routine validation of remote sensing products? To our knowledge, an in-depth and comprehensive study on this issue has not been performed to this date. Sporadic, related researches mainly focus on discussions of sampling errors between the kilometer-scale and the grid-scale spaces. Therefore, it is necessary to thoroughly investigate and quantify the representativeness errors from the point-scale to the kilometer-scale, to the grid-scale.

Ground-based solar radiation measurements are frequently used for directly validating satellite-derived surface solar radiation (SSR) products and even correcting any biases in the remote sensing products. Nevertheless, we realize that their spatial representativeness is per se different, and differences of observations and products not only are caused by the product-generating algorithms themselves but also by poor representativeness of surface sites. Moreover, we note that representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based solar radiation measurements are also related to the local climate and weather regimes, especially cloud climatology. Thus, representativeness of surface measurements is region-specific.
research objective: In this paper, we will investigate and quantify the representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based measurements using the surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER (Li et al., 2013) and the solar radiation data retrieved from geostationary meteorological satellite (Huang, Li, Ma, & Li, 2016).

Our primary purpose is investigating the representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based SSR measurements with respect to kilometer-level and grid-level surroundings. By analyzing representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based SSR measurements with respect to different levels of areas (kilometer-level or grid-level), implications for the routine validation of remote sensing products are drawn and presented finally.

In this paper, we first investigate the inadequate spatial representativeness of ground-based solar radiation measurements and quantify the representativeness errors of point measurements with respect to larger surroundings. Our study demonstrates that wildly fluctuating representativeness errors indeed exist in the routine validation of remote sensing products, which strongly depend on their time and space scales as well as instant atmospheric conditions. Our practical validation via utilizing the high-density SSR matrix observations further points out that on the instantaneous and 0.05° time-space scales the error due to the inadequate representativeness of point-scale measurements increases the final RMSE by approximately 13.4%. Our discussion on representativeness errors will promote a better assessment for different types of remote sensing products using ground-based observations, and thereby is also beneficial to the further improvements of the quality of satellite-derived products.
challenges: Questions such as, how large is the representativeness error of surface measurements in the validation and how much of the product-measurement difference can be attributed to their inherent differing spatial scales, cast doubts on the suitability of this direct validation approach.

Compared to other routine meteorological parameters, the measurements of surface radiation components are more prone to all kinds of errors. However, due to the limitation of our observed data (direct beam radiation and diffuse radiation were not measured independently in the experiment), it is very difficult to find a valid approach to correct the leveling-induced error. One natural challenge for current high spatial resolution SSR satellite products is the cloud inhomogeneity given the fact that 3D radiative transfer effects are neglected in the retrieval scheme.

As spatial coverage increases, a single observation site really increasingly can not represent the areal means of the grid, even if the site is located at the center of the grid. Here representativeness error probably has a great influence on routine validation results because compared with kilometer-level products grid-level products are insensitive to some errors (e.g., the error from cloud inhomogeneity and 3D radiative transfer effects).
methods: First, "areal SSR" on the kilometer-scale was estimated by a simple multi-point averaging method. That is, the "areal SSR" over the 1×1 km2 and the 5×5 km2 domains were separately estimated by averaging the measurements from Sites 4, 6 and 7, and all sites except Site 16. Second, measured SSR from each individual site were compared with the estimates of areal SSR, and differences between them were deemed the representativeness error from point to kilometer scales. Representativeness error of point-scale measurements with respect to grid-level surrounding include two levels of errors, namely detailed error from point to kilometer scales and macroscopic error from kilometer to grid scales. Accordingly, the macroscopic representativeness errors for the 0.25° × 0.25°, 0.50° × 0.50° and 1° × 1° grid domains were separately calculated using the satellite products of 0.05° resolution produced by us before. During the matrix experiment, all measurements were carried out carefully with continuous supervision. Spirit levels and glass domes of the 17 radiometers were checked weekly to guard against any perceptible instrument tilting and possible soiling of the sensors.
dataset: As mentioned earlier, surface observation data in this study are only provided by the surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER-MUSOEXE. This observation matrix includes 17 sets of eddy covariance (EC) system and automatic meteorological station and 4 pairs of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) systems, and covers approximately 5 × 5 km2 spatial area located in the midstream area of Heihe river basin, northwest China. Previous SSR satellite products over Heihe river basin in northwest China are used in the current study. The products were based on the look-up table algorithm of Huang, Ma, Liang, Liu, and Li (2011), and the Japanese second generation geostationary meteorological satellite, Multifunctional Transport Satellite (MTSAT). The original spatial resolution of the products is 0.05° (~5 km), and the temporal resolution is half hour.
findings: The current study demonstrates that wildly fluctuating representativeness errors exist which are strongly contingent on the time and space scales of remote sensing products, as well as instant atmospheric conditions. For example, for an area of 5 × 5 km2 1.4~8.1% of representativeness errors are found from monthly to “instantaneous” timescales; while for an area of 1° × 1° grid 3.1~8.1% of representativeness errors are seen. Such scale-dependent representativeness errors offer some implications for validations of remote sensing products. On timescales longer than or equal to one day, representativeness errors do not need to be considered for validations of kilometer-level products, but on shorter timescales representativeness errors will affect the validation results to some extent. For instantaneous products with 5 km resolution, our study indicates over 13% of errors can be attributed to the inherent representativeness error, and 30-minute surface measurements are recommended for a routine validation. However, for validations of grid-level products, representativeness errors basically cannot be neglected regardless of timescales. The errors caused by the poor representativeness of surface sites, likely significantly contribute to the large differences between measurements and products.

For the 1 × 1 km2 domain, 3.2~21.9 W/m2 of RMSD and 1.2~4.4% of RMD are found with the smaller value for monthly timescale and larger one for "instantaneous" timescale; whereas for the 5 × 5 km2 domain, 3.2~40.2 W/m2 of RMSD and 1.2~8.1% of RMD are seen, respectively. Meanwhile, representativeness errors of point-scale measurements with respect to the grid-level areas were discussed based on the combined efforts from HiWATER-MUSOEXE and the previous satellite products. Within the 0.25° × 0.25° grid, the composite RMSD and RMD respectively are 5.1~53.9 W/m2 and 1.9~9.8% corresponding to the monthly till the instantaneous averaging intervals; within the 0.50° × 0.50° grid, the range of composite RMSD and RMD are 6.3~70.3 W/m2 and 2.2~12.7%, respectively; while within the 1° × 1° grid, they are 8.8~91.7 W/m2 and 3.3~16.6%, respectively.

Our study demonstrates that wildly fluctuating representativeness errors indeed exist in the routine validation of remote sensing products, which strongly depend on their time and space scales as well as instant atmospheric conditions. For the most common 5 × 5 km2 domain, the RMSD of the “instantaneous” representativeness error is about 40 W/m2 (~8.1% of the mean SSR); whereas for the standard 1° × 1° grid domain, the RMSD of the instantaneous representativeness error is as great as 91 W/m2 (~16.1% of the mean SSR). Such scale-dependent representativeness errors conversely provide critical constraints on the direct comparisons of surface measurements and satellite products, and thus are valuable for narrowing down the uncertainty range between them. For a kilometer-level SSR product, if its timescale is longer than or even equal to one day, in validation the error originating from their different spatial footprints can be completely neglected. However, if its timescale is less than one day, representativeness error has a certain influence on the validation result, especially for instantaneous products.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes in a heterogeneous environment?
Example.Answer: One example is the use of hierarchically nested scales with instrumentation such as eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and a sparse network of eco-hydrological sensors to capture multi-scale processes in the oasis-desert area as part of the HiWATER experiment.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced during the validation of remote sensing products using ground-based measurements?
Example.Answer: A challenge in the validation process is the representativeness error due to differing spatial scales between point-scale ground-based measurements and satellite remote sensing products, which impacts the accuracy of validation results.

Definition.Question: What are 'multiscale observations' in the context of eco-hydrological research, and why are they important?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations refer to data collection efforts that capture eco-hydrological processes at various spatial and temporal scales. They are important because they help address challenges related to the poor availability of data across different scales, which is essential for understanding complex ecosystem interactions and processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Definition.Question: What does 'representativeness error' mean in the validation of remote sensing products, and how does it affect the process?
Definition.Answer: Representativeness error refers to the discrepancy that arises when point-scale ground-based measurements are used to validate larger scale remote sensing products. This error occurs due to the differing spatial samplings between point-specific measurements and areal or grid-level satellite products. It affects the validation process by potentially introducing significant differences between measurements and satellite-derived products, especially on shorter timescales or when spatial coverage is large.

Definition.Question: What does 'hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing' entail, and what role does it play in eco-hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing involves using advanced imaging technologies, such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers, to capture highly detailed data from the air. This method plays a crucial role in eco-hydrological data collection by providing precise and comprehensive spatial data that can enhance the understanding of surface processes and validate ground-based measurements.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques for soil temperature and moisture in the BNUNET sensor network compare to those used in the HiWATER eco-hydrological sensor network?
Comparison.Answer: The BNUNET sensor network collects soil temperature and moisture data at specific depths with a fixed frequency, using a network of nodes in a defined matrix. In contrast, the HiWATER eco-hydrological sensor network is part of a larger multiscale observation system that includes eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, focusing on a broader set of environmental parameters and processes.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be gained about regional climate and weather regimes from the observed discrepancies in solar radiation measurements between ground-based and satellite-derived data?
Interpretation.Answer: The discrepancies highlight that ground-based solar radiation measurements can be affected by local climate and cloud conditions, which vary regionally. This suggests that these measurements may not be fully representative of the broader area captured by satellite data, pointing to the necessity of considering local meteorological influences when interpreting solar radiation datasets.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies of heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in the field of eco-hydrological studies is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. This challenge is addressed through experiments like HiWATER, which use instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do representativeness errors occur when validating satellite-derived surface solar radiation products using ground-based measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Representativeness errors occur due to the differing spatial scales of satellite products and ground-based measurements. Satellite products provide areal retrieved values over satellite pixel footprints, whereas ground-based measurements are point-specific. This scale diversity, along with local climate, weather regimes, and cloud climatology, can lead to errors in validation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the inadequacy of spatial representativeness in ground-based solar radiation measurements when compared to larger scale satellite products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The inadequacy of spatial representativeness in ground-based measurements stems from their point-specific nature, which does not accurately reflect the larger surrounding areas characterized by satellite products. This is compounded by the spatial and temporal variability of atmospheric conditions and cloud cover, leading to representativeness errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from the limited availability of multiscale observations on the upscaling of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The limited availability of multiscale observations could hinder progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes, as these processes require detailed data across different scales. The HiWATER experiment attempts to address this by using a hierarchical approach to capture multiscale data, which is essential for understanding the complex interactions in such environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions using eco-hydrological sensor networks?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions is crucial because it helps capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes that are a grand challenge due to the heterogeneity of the surface. The network allows for the collection of multi-scale and multidisciplinary data, addressing the limited availability of such observations, which hinders progress in understanding these interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to quantify the representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based measurements in the validation of remote sensing products?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Quantifying the representativeness errors of point-scale ground-based measurements is necessary because these errors can significantly affect the validation results of remote sensing products. The spatial representativeness of surface measurements varies, and understanding these errors is crucial for improving the accuracy of validations and ensuring that the satellite-derived products accurately reflect the larger area they represent.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are representativeness errors of ground-based solar radiation measurements quantified when validating satellite-derived surface solar radiation products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Representativeness errors are quantified by comparing point-scale ground-based measurements with areal SSR estimates over kilometer-scale and grid-scale domains. The study uses a simple multi-point averaging method to estimate areal SSR at different scales and calculates the differences between point measurements and these estimates to determine representativeness errors. The analysis considers both detailed errors from point to kilometer scales and macroscopic errors from kilometer to grid scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the quality control of observational data in the collection process for eco-hydrological studies in the Heihe river basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: All observational data are carefully quality controlled through rigorous sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and dataset generation. During experiments, continuous supervision is maintained, with regular checks of spirit levels and glass domes of radiometers to prevent instrument tilting and sensor soiling, ensuring data integrity and accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What conditions enable the successful deployment of a wireless sensor network for eco-hydrological observations in a heterogeneous terrain?
Enablement.Answer: The deployment of a wireless sensor network for eco-hydrological observations in a heterogeneous terrain is enabled by the arrangement of sensors in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale processes, as demonstrated in the HiWATER experiment. This involves establishing a sparse network to investigate interactions, constructing stations within key areas, and using remote sensing missions to cover extensive regions.

Enablement.Question: What are the key technological advancements that enable the accurate validation of satellite-derived surface solar radiation products using ground-based measurements?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate validation of satellite-derived surface solar radiation products using ground-based measurements is enabled by the understanding and quantification of representativeness errors between point-scale and larger-scale measurements. Methodological advancements, such as the use of high-density SSR matrix observations and the development of algorithms to estimate areal SSR, provide critical insights into spatial sampling differences and improve validation accuracy.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have regarding the integration of multiscale observations in addressing eco-hydrological challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect multiscale observations to provide a more comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes across heterogeneous surfaces, thereby improving the validation and accuracy of satellite products through hierarchical instrumentation and diverse data collection methods.

Expectation.Question: Why could the scarcity of multiscale observations hinder progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes?
Expectation.Answer: The scarcity of multiscale observations limits the ability to capture comprehensive data across different scales and disciplines, which is crucial for understanding complex interactions in eco-hydrological systems and for developing effective models and validation techniques.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using hierarchically nested scales for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in this domain?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of hierarchically nested scales is considered effective for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, as it allows for detailed and varied data collection that addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations. The HiWATER experiment effectively utilizes this approach by arranging instruments in a nested manner to investigate interactions in an oasis-desert system, capturing a wide range of eco-hydrological data.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the challenges associated with representativeness errors in validating remote sensing products using point-scale ground-based measurements in this domain?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges associated with representativeness errors are significant due to the inherent differences in spatial scales between ground-based measurements and remote sensing products. These errors can greatly influence validation results, especially for high spatial resolution SSR satellite products where cloud inhomogeneity and other factors are not accounted for. It is crucial to thoroughly investigate and quantify these errors to improve the accuracy of validation processes.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the potential for improving the accuracy of remote sensing product validation through enhanced data collection techniques in this field?
Judgmental.Answer: Improving the accuracy of remote sensing product validation can be achieved by enhancing data collection techniques, such as using a multi-point averaging method to estimate areal SSR, ensuring continuous supervision of measurements, and addressing representativeness errors. By considering the scale-dependent nature of representativeness errors and employing high-density observation networks like the HiWATER-MUSOEXE, validation processes can be refined to reduce uncertainties.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how multiscale observations are effectively used to study eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces.
Assertion.Answer: Multiscale observations are utilized in the HiWATER experiment by employing instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, which includes flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing. This allows researchers to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and address the challenge of poor availability of such observations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the data collection methods for validating satellite-derived surface solar radiation products.
Assertion.Answer: Validation of satellite-derived surface solar radiation (SSR) products often involves comparing satellite estimates with ground-based measurements. However, due to differences in spatial sampling scales, such as point-scale for ground measurements and grid-scale for satellite products, representativeness errors can occur. These errors are examined using the surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER, which includes a network of eddy covariance systems and automatic meteorological stations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest strategies for addressing the challenge of multiscale observation scarcity in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies to address multiscale observation scarcity include designing experiments like HiWATER that use hierarchically nested instrumentation to capture multiscale data. Implementing intensive observation periods (IOPs) alongside continuous hydrometeorological observations can fill data gaps. Utilizing a superstation in an oasis, along with multiple EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in surrounding landscapes, can gather diverse data points. Additionally, conducting remote sensing missions with various sensors can provide essential data to address scale discrepancies.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential methodologies to quantify and reduce the representativeness errors in the validation of satellite-derived SSR products using ground-based observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: To quantify and reduce representativeness errors, methodologies should include estimating 'areal SSR' using multi-point averaging methods over specified domains. Comparing these averaged values with individual site measurements can help determine representativeness errors. Regular calibration and maintenance of measuring instruments, such as checking spirit levels and cleaning sensors, ensure data accuracy. Furthermore, utilizing high-density observation matrices, such as the surface flux-observation matrix from HiWATER, can improve spatial coverage and provide more representative data for validation.
